name: Seattle
fun_fact: Fun fact: Washington State farms more oysters than any other U.S. state, and Seattle takes this so seriously that The Walrus and the Carpenter oyster bar became famous enough that reservations are nearly impossible - proving that Seattleites will wait hours for perfectly fresh bivalves.

hero_dishes.name: Fresh Pacific Oysters
hero_dishes.description: Local oysters from Hama Hama, Taylor Shellfish Farms, and other Washington producers - briny, sweet, and ocean-fresh
hero_dishes.origin_story: Washington's cold Pacific waters produce some of the world's best oysters. Seattle's obsession with them has created a thriving oyster bar culture where locals can identify oysters by their growing region like wine
hero_dishes.where_to_find: The Walrus and the Carpenter (regarded as the best), Taylor Shellfish Farms, Westward (Lake Union views), Bar Melusine (Capitol Hill)

hero_dishes.name: Hand-Pulled Noodles at Noodle/Bar
hero_dishes.description: Every strand hand-pulled from Washington wheat by Chef Travis Post - served in rich broth with beef meatballs, wood-ear mushrooms, and chile oil
hero_dishes.origin_story: Chef Post pulls every single noodle by hand, a meditative process that creates irregular, perfectly textured strands. This is Seattle's answer to artisanal pasta - rainy-day therapy in a bowl
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Noodle/Bar (new to Resy's Fall 2025 Hit List)

hero_dishes.name: Tajarin con Burro e Salvia at Spinasse
hero_dishes.description: Fresh pasta with butter and sage - deceptively simple, impossibly delicious
hero_dishes.origin_story: Chef Stuart Lane focuses on traditional Piedmont dishes at what many consider Seattle's best fresh pasta restaurant. The tajarin (thin egg noodles) are rolled and cut by hand daily
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Spinasse (makes case for best fresh pasta in Seattle)

hero_dishes.name: Sichuan-Style Fried Chicken
hero_dishes.description: Crispy chicken with Sichuan peppercorns creating a numbing, tingling sensation alongside heat
hero_dishes.origin_story: At Plenty of Clouds, bold Sichuan and Yunnan flavors dominate. The fried chicken with Sichuan peppercorns showcases Seattle's exceptional Asian food scene
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Plenty of Clouds (Sichuan and Yunnan flavors), various Asian restaurants in Seattle's International District

signature_drinks.name: Craft Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Third-wave coffee roasted locally - Seattle is the birthplace of coffee culture in America
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Despite Starbucks being from Seattle, locals prefer independent roasters and pour-over methods. Coffee is a religion here, consumed constantly regardless of weather

signature_drinks.name: Local Craft Beer
signature_drinks.description: IPAs and other craft beers from Seattle's thriving brewery scene
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: At breweries like Fair Isle Brewing (which houses La Marea Mexican seafood counter). The Pacific Northwest pioneered the craft beer movement

food_culture_notes: Seattle Met's 2025 best new restaurants list shows the city's resourcefulness and innovation
La Marea serves Mexican-style seafood like scallop aguachile inside Fair Isle Brewing
The Pink Door has been popular for decades - an intimate Italian restaurant hidden down Post Alley
Kamonegi offers hand-cut soba noodles in a cozy space with traditional Japanese decor

unique_modern: tech industry wealth meeting food culture
Asian cuisine excellence rivaling traditional American food
